newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Brussels bourse lags Europe but seen holding level.
newsitem.headline: Brussels bourse lags Europe but seen holding level.

text.p: The Brussels bourse edged higher in early trading on Wednesday, lagging its European neighbours, but traders said they saw no reason for a reversal with the market happy at current levels.
"There are no specific reasons for it to rise or to fall from here. The dollar is up a bit and Wall Street's overnight drop was just light profittaking," one trader said.
"Yesterday we were fairly neutral, although there was some quite significant buying in specific shares such as PetroFina which really helped to underpin the whole market," the trader added.
Traders said the market was watching for U.S. April producer price index figures due at 1230 GMT. The figures are seen unchanged month-on-month and up 1.5 percent year-on-year.
They said that while a number of company annual meetings were due to take place during Wednesday, there were no expectations of anything specific.
Insurer Dexia, fast food retailer Quick and non-ferrous metals group Union Miniere are among the companies holding either annual or extraordinary general meetings today.
Quick was an early victim, dropping more than six percent at one stage after the company said in a newspaper interview the first four months of 1997 had been flat.
By 0900 GMT it had crept back to 1,940 francs -- a loss of 4.9 percent.
Parent company GIB also suffered, dropping 2.6 percent to 1,520 francs.
On the plus side Distrigas was an early star, rising 5.4 percent to 29,500 francs in reaction to positive comments at the firm's annual meeting on Tuesday.
Builder Franki likewise added strongly to its recent jet propelled performance, climbing 4.0 percent to 520 francs.
Traders said the rise was due to fading worries among shareholders over the loss making company's fate.
But they noted that the volume was low and the share movements therefore exaggerated.
At 0920 GMT the Bel-20 blue chip share index was 0.25 percent up at 2,248.58, with some 750 million francs of Belgian shares traded.
